moves.1. e4: My first learning game, rated as 1150 as a fairly new player.
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5: White opens with Ruy Lopez, and I open with the Berlin Defence.
moves.3... Nf6 4. O-O: I note that White castles early in the game.
moves.4... Bc5: I develop my bishop and place it on a diagonal with the white king.  I am getting ready to castle.
moves.5. c3: I first saw whites pawn push as preventing me from pushing my knight forward, or for a d4 pawn push to attack the center.
moves.5... O-O 6. d4: White follows up with d4 attacking my bishop and pawn on e5.
moves.6... exd4: I thought it was best to take otherwise I would lose the exchange.
moves.8. e5 Nd5 9. a4: White pushes pawn to a4 and at this point each side was about equal.
moves.9... h6: Blunder number 1.  I thought h6 helped block certain threats I was anticipating.  However....on the other side of the board white had other ideas...
moves.10. Bxc6 dxc6: I'm not sure if I used the right pawn to take here.  My thoughts at the time were that it keeps the pawns grouped together and opens up my bishop.  However the weakness is that I have no center pawns and white has two.
moves.11. a5: This is why my earlier move h6 was a blunder.  Instead I should have pushed my a7 pawn to a5 to protect my bishop that has now become trapped!
moves.11... Bxa5 12. Rxa5 f6: Here, I see an opportunity to attack the pawn and bring my queen in to the game.
moves.13. exf6 Qxf6 14. Ne5: Whites knight on e5 is very problematic, and I have lost my dark square bishop and have no center pawns to attack with.   I now miss my d7 pawn!
moves.14... Bf5: I attack an unprotected knight and develop my bishop.  I think a much better move would have been to attack the rook on a5, following up with attacking whites central pawn - I was planning to do this after developing the bishop but white had something else in mind and I lost the opportunity.
moves.15. Nc3: I'm down in material and an exchange of knights would worsen my situation from this position.
moves.15... Ne7: I think a better move would have been to attack the rook and central pawn by pushing my pawns up.
moves.16. Qb3+: Check - another issue with losing my central pawn!  Additionally, if I attacked the Rook earlier with my b7 pawn I would have prevented the queen fork!  I didn't attack the rook because I thought it could too easily get out of trouble, and pushing the pawn up one square seemed insignificant at the time.  Whilst I was keeping at eye out for whites queen I was expecting it to come across to my kings side...not the other way!
moves.16... Kh7 17. Qxb7: Now I have lost my b7 pawn I no longer have a good opportunity to attack whites central pawn.
moves.17... Rfc8 18. Re1 Ng6: Here I moved the Knight to g6 hoping white may exchange.  My strategy was to get my Queen on g6 and then my Bishop on h3 threatening white King.
moves.19... Be6: Blunder no. 2!  I really should have swapped Queens...I was determined to stick to my strategy without reassessing the situation.
moves.20. Nxg6 Rce8: I can't take the Knight without further losses, so instead I move Rook to e6 which protects my Bishop and Queen
moves.21. Ne5 Qe7: Considered Rook to f8, but this is too obvious and easily countered by white.  Instead I protect my pawn.
moves.22. Qe4+ Kg8: I moved the King to g8.  Moving to h8 would be a problem for my Queen if white moved the Knight to g6 creating a fork.
moves.23. Bxh6: White can afford to sacrifice the Bishop, however I decide not to take it as my Pawn is offering my King some protection.
moves.23... Qf6 24. Bxg7 Kxg7 25. Re3 Reg8: Moved my Rook to g8 to offer some attack after check...
moves.26. Rg3+ Kf8: The computer analysis of King to h8 shows a better outcome, with f8 I leave my rook on a8 unprotected.
moves.27. Qxa8+ Ke7 28. Rxg8 Qh6 29. Qd8#:
Things I learned from this game:

1) Pawns!!!  They are more powerful than I've given them credit for, and I need to consider my opponent's pawn pushes more carefully.

2) Make sure major pieces don't become trapped.

3) Consider all the pieces, and don't get too analytical over just a selection of pieces or else things easily get missed.

4) If you see an opportunity - don't delay.

5) Think more carefully about the placement of my pawns when taking - not just for the next move but for the latter stages of the game.

6) If opponent's move doesn't appear to have a purpose, then stop and consider it more carefully.

opening: Ruy Lopez (C65), Berlin defence, Beverwijk variation
